If bodhisattvas think like this:

They do not see the emptiness of the unconditioned, and do not rely on the emptiness of the unconditioned to contemplate the emptiness of the conditioned, and do not rely on the emptiness of the unconditioned to contemplate the emptiness of the ultimate;ğŸ”½They do not see the emptiness of the ultimate, and do not rely on the emptiness of the ultimate to contemplate the emptiness of the unconditioned, and do not rely on the emptiness of the ultimate to contemplate the emptiness of the boundless;

They do not see the emptiness of non-dispersal, and do not rely on the emptiness of non-dispersal to contemplate the emptiness of the boundless, and do not rely on the emptiness of non-dispersal to contemplate the emptiness of the intrinsic nature;

They do not see the emptiness of the intrinsic nature, and do not rely on the emptiness of the intrinsic nature to contemplate the emptiness of non-dispersal, and do not rely on the emptiness of the intrinsic nature to contemplate the emptiness of characteristics;

ÅšÄriputra!

Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they should study the profound prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ like this: they should know form and name but not become attached to them, they should know feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness and name but not become attached to them;

I do not know, obtain, or see prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ at all. If I were to instruct and teach bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas with prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, I would certainly regret it.

World-Honored One!

World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the form realm up to the dharma realm. How can it be said that this is the form realm up to the dharma realm?
The names of the form realm and so forth are all without abiding and also not non-abiding.

World-Honored One!

I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the eye consciousness realm up to the mind consciousness realm. How can it be said that this is the eye consciousness realm up to the mind consciousness realm?

Why is it so?
Because the meaning of the eye consciousness realm and so forth is non-existent, the name of the eye consciousness realm and so forth does not abide anywhere and is also not non-abiding.
World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in eye contact up to mental contact. How can it be said that this is eye contact up to mental contact?

I do not know, obtain, or see the increase or decrease of ignorance up to old age and death. How can one say this is ignorance up to old age and death?

World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in generosity up to the perfection of wisdom. How can one say this is generosity up to the perfection of wisdom?

World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the self, up to the seer. How can it be said that this is the self, up to the seer?

I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the four establishments of mindfulness, up to the eightfold noble path. How can it be said that this is the four establishments of mindfulness, up to the eightfold noble path?

World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the three gates of liberation, so how can I say 'these are the three gates of liberation'?

Because the meaning of the three gates of liberation is non-existent, the names of the three gates of liberation all abide nowhere and are not non-abiding.

I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the concentrations, immeasurables, and formless [absorptions], so how can I say 'these are the concentrations, immeasurables, and formless [absorptions]'?
The names of the concentrations, etc. all abide nowhere and are not non-abiding.

I do not know, obtain, or see whether the five eyes and six supernormal powers increase or decrease. How can I say this is the five eyes and six supernormal powers?

I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in the ten powers of the Buddha up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha. How can I speak of these as the ten powers of the Buddha up to the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha?

Because the meaning of conditioned phenomena and so forth does not exist, the names of conditioned phenomena and so forth do not abide anywhere, nor do they not abide.
World-Honored One!
I do not know, obtain, or see any increase or decrease in past, future, or present phenomena. How can one say these are past, future, or present phenomena?

Because the meaning of the past and so forth does not exist, the names of the past and so forth do not abide anywhere, nor do they not abide.

What is internal emptiness?
Internal refers to internal dharmas, namely the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
One should know that here, the eyes are empty due to the eyes, not permanent and not destroyed.
Why is it so?
Because the inherent nature is thus.

Why is it so?
Because the inherent nature is thus.
This is called internal emptiness.
What is external emptiness?
External refers to external dharmas, namely form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
You should know that in this case, form is empty due to form, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.

Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.
This is called external emptiness.
What is internal and external emptiness?
Internal and external refers to internal and external dharmas, namely the six internal sense bases and the six external sense bases.
You should know that in this case, internal dharmas are empty due to external dharmas, neither ceasing nor eternal.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature, namely, the six internal sense bases are empty due to the six external sense bases.

Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature, namely, the six external sense bases are empty due to the six internal sense bases.
This is called internal and external emptiness.
What is great emptiness?

Because of the inherent nature.

Why is it so?

This is called emptiness of emptiness.

This is called emptiness of the ultimate.

Why is it so?

Why is it so?

This is called the emptiness of the unconditioned.

The ultimate refers to a Dharma that is ultimately unobtainable.
One should know that the ultimate is empty of the ultimate, neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is it so?
Because of the inherent nature.
This is called the emptiness of the ultimate.
What is the emptiness of the beginningless?

The beginningless refers to a Dharma that cannot be apprehended as having a beginning, middle, or end. If a Dharma cannot be apprehended as having a beginning, middle, or end, then that Dharma does not come and does not go.
One should know that the absence of a beginning or end is due to the emptiness of the absence of a beginning or end, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is this?
Because this is the intrinsic nature.
This is called the emptiness of the absence of a beginning or end.
What is the emptiness of non-rejection?
Rejection refers to the abandonment, relinquishment, and letting go of all dharmas that can be attained. If a dharma cannot be abandoned, relinquished, or let go of, it is called non-rejection.
Here, the absence of rejection is due to the emptiness of non-rejection, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is this?
Because this is the intrinsic nature.
This is called the emptiness of non-rejection.
What is the emptiness of intrinsic nature?

Intrinsic nature refers to the nature of all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas. Such an intrinsic nature is not created by the hearers, not created by the solitary realizers, not created by the bodhisattvas, not created by the buddhas, and not created by anyone else. Its nature is such that it is called intrinsic nature.
One should know that the intrinsic nature is due to the emptiness of intrinsic nature, which is neither permanent nor perishable.
Why is this?
Because this is the intrinsic nature.
This is called the emptiness of inherent nature.
What is the emptiness of characteristics?
Characteristics refer to the specific characteristics and common characteristics of dharmas.
One should know that here, characteristics are empty of characteristics, neither ceasing nor arising.
Why is this?
Because the inherent nature is so.
This is called the emptiness of characteristics.
What is the emptiness of all dharmas?

All dharmas refer to form, sensation, perception, impulse, and consciousness; eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind; form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and mental objects; eye-consciousness, up to mind-consciousness; eye-contact, up to mind-contact; the sensations produced by eye-contact as a condition, up to the sensations produced by mind-contact as a condition; conditioned dharmas, and unconditioned dharmas, are called all dharmas.
Here, all dharmas are empty of all dharmas, neither ceasing nor arising.
Why is this?
Because the inherent nature is so.
This is called the emptiness of all dharmas.
What is the emptiness of naturelessness?
Naturelessness refers to the fact that in this [emptiness], not even a little nature can be apprehended.
One should know that the absence of intrinsic nature is due to the emptiness of intrinsic nature, neither ceasing nor permanent.
Why is it so?
Because the fundamental nature is thus.
This is called the emptiness of the absence of intrinsic nature.
What is the emptiness of the absence of intrinsic nature of non-entities?
The absence of intrinsic nature of non-entities refers to the nature of all dharmas that cannot be combined with the nature of that which can be combined. Because they arise from various conditions,
one should know that the absence of intrinsic nature of non-entities is due to the emptiness of the absence of intrinsic nature of non-entities, neither ceasing nor permanent.
Why is it so?
Because the fundamental nature is thus.

What is the existence of an intrinsic nature due to the emptiness of the intrinsic nature of existence?
The existence of an intrinsic nature refers to conditioned dharmas, which are the five aggregates.

Such an existence of an intrinsic nature is due to the emptiness of the intrinsic nature of existence, because the five aggregates such as form cannot be apprehended and have the nature of non-arising.
What is the non-existence of an intrinsic nature due to the emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence?
The absence of intrinsic nature refers to unconditioned dharmas. Here, unconditioned dharmas are empty of unconditioned dharmas, which is the emptiness of the absence of intrinsic nature.
How is intrinsic nature empty of intrinsic nature?

It is said that all dharmas are empty of intrinsic nature. This emptiness is not created by cognition, not created by views, and not created by anything else. Therefore, it is called the emptiness of intrinsic nature of intrinsic nature.
How is extrinsic nature empty of extrinsic nature?

It is said that all dharmas, whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not, abide in the Dharma, are determined by the Dharma, are the realm of the Dharma, are suchness, are non-false nature, are unchanging nature, are the ultimate reality, and are the principle of the Dharma. They are empty of extrinsic nature. Therefore, it is called the emptiness of extrinsic nature of extrinsic nature.

What are the eleven?

They are the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of exhaustion, the knowledge of non-arising, the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of categories, the knowledge of convention, the knowledge of others' minds, and the knowledge as it is.
What is the knowledge of suffering?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that suffering should not arise, this is the knowledge of suffering.
What is the knowledge of the origin [of suffering]?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that the origin [of suffering] should be eternally severed, this is the knowledge of the origin [of suffering].
What is the knowledge of the cessation [of suffering]?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that cessation should be realized, this is the knowledge of the cessation [of suffering].
What is the knowledge of the path [leading to the cessation of suffering]?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that the path should be cultivated, this is the knowledge of the path [leading to the cessation of suffering].
What is the knowledge of extinction?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that greed, hatred, and delusion are extinguished, this is the knowledge of extinction.
What is the knowledge of non-arising?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know that all existences will not arise again, this is the knowledge of non-arising.
What is the knowledge of dharmas?
It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know the individual natures of the five aggregates and so forth, this is called the knowledge of dharmas.
What is inferential knowledge?

It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know the distinguishing characteristics of the five aggregates and so forth, such as suffering, impermanence, emptiness, no-self, and so forth, this is called inferential knowledge.
What is conventional knowledge?

It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know the differences in the practices of sentient beings, and to know the differences in the names, characteristics, and so forth of all dharmas, this is called conventional knowledge.
What is knowledge of others' minds?

It means that if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know the mental and mental factors of other sentient beings and individuals without any doubt or hesitation, this is called knowledge of others' minds.

That is to say, if wisdom uses non-attainment as a skillful means to know all dharmas as they are described, this is precisely the TathÄgata's wisdom of all aspects. This is called the wisdom as described.
